awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Action, Learning, and Social Cognition
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to understand other people's goals and intentions is critical for social competence. A key component of this is interpreting the reasons for others' actions. Infants appear to be able to determine others' goals based on observing others' actions early in life, and this sensitivity to others' goals is associated with developments in infants' own ability to perform goal-based actions. The purpose of this project is to investigate the neural and cognitive systems that support infants' emerging sensitivity to goal-based actions in themselves and others. This work will shed new light on how neurocognitive development supports early social cognition. 

The proposed studies will record electroencephalogram (EEG), a technique for recording the brain's electrical activity, while 8- to 10-month-old infants perform actions on objects, when they perform joint actions with others, and when they observe others' actions.  A first goal of the research is to characterize the neural processes that are involved when infants learn to engage in new actions and social collaborations. A second goal is to test the prediction that these neural processes also support infants' understanding of others' goal-directed actions. To address these issues, the research will evaluate networks of neural activity as infants act and observe others' actions, and will assess whether these patterns of neural activity predict when infants are able to respond appropriately to others' goal-directed actions. Beyond addressing the focal research questions, the proposed studies will generate new approaches to analyzing infant neural and cognitive development, and the findings of these studies with typically-developing infants may help to shed light on developmental disorders that affect social cognition and social behavior. The project will provide unique multidisciplinary training opportunities for students and postdoctoral researchers.

por.por_cntn:
At the core of human social competence is the ability to make sense of other people’s goals. Infants’ brain activity and their behavior suggest that they respond selectively to the goal structure of others’ actions. Infants’ sensitivity to others’ goals sets the stage for social and cognitive development. Two bodies of research suggest that the relevant processes involve in the development of social cognition involved the mechanisms that support an infants’ own actions. One body of work has revealed connections between infants’ action experience and their sensitivity to others’ goals. A second body of research indicates that, as with adults, when infants watch others’ actions, their own motor system becomes active. Together, these two bodies of work raise an intriguing possibility -- the foundational developments in action control that occur during infancy may support the emergence of a critical aspect of social perception, that is, sensitivity to the goals in others’ actions. This project is a collaboration between the laboratories of Professor Amanda Woodward at the University of Chicago and Professor Nathan Fox at the University of Maryland. A series of studies are being completed at Woodward’s lab using both behavioral and electrophysiological measures to examine the development of infant social cognition. The Fox lab has provided the technical, methodological, and conceptual support for using electrophysiological approaches to measuring infant brain activity. The  studies address this gap in knowledge by integrating neural and behavioral measures in studies of the plasticity of infant social cognition.

Over the course of the award, we have developed and refined a pre-processing pipeline for the use with infant electrophysiological data. This software pipeline has been tested on multiple infant EEG data sets and compared to current standard approaches and has been found to perform better in that it removes artifact and environmental noise from infant EEG data. The result is a “clean” EEG data set that can then be analyzed to examine infant neural responses during experimental paradigms.

The Fox lab has, in addition, provided technical support to the Woodward lab for the set- up of an EEG lab at the University of Chicago and has been in constant contact with students at the Woodward lab on the acquisition, pre-processing, and analysis of EEG data. The results of this activity have led to the conduct of multiple experiments and to the submission and acceptance of multiple scientific reports on the emergence of infant social understanding integrating both brain and behavioral measures.

A major outcome of this project is the training of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows at both locations (University of Chicago and University of Maryland) in both electrophysiology and also infant social cognition. Students from each lab traveled to the other and spent time learning the experimental methods and approaches to the study of infant social cognition.
